ref.comment: Points to “this Subpart B”, bringing all of its requirements to bear on turbine-powered aeroplanes addressed by the paragraph.
The AMC is cited only as non-binding explanatory material to help applicants understand acceptable means of compliance.
The paragraph requires the applicant to show compliance with the system-safety rule in CS 25.671 whenever flight characteristics rely on an automated system.
CS 25.672 is likewise incorporated as a mandatory design rule for automatic or power-operated systems that affect flight characteristics.
The wind-measurement rule applies specifically when showing compliance with the take-off distance requirement of CS 25.105(d).
Wind must be measured as specified whenever demonstrating compliance with the landing-distance rule of CS 25.125.
The same wind-measurement requirement applies when showing compliance with the directional-stability rule CS 25.233.
Wind measurement at 10 m is also mandated for compliance demonstrations under the maneuver-stability rule CS 25.237.
The AMC is cited only for explanatory guidance on how to interpret or demonstrate the scope statement.
CS 25.121(a) is specifically exempted, so its take-off performance requirement does not have to be met in Appendix C icing.
CS 25.123(c) is excluded from the icing-compliance obligation.
The basic longitudinal-control requirement of CS 25.143(b)(1) is carved out of the icing compliance set.
CS 25.143(b)(2) is likewise excluded from the obligation to show compliance in Appendix C icing.
The maneuvering-speed requirement CS 25.149 is on the exclusion list, so it need not be met in Appendix C icing.
The specific stall-warning sub-paragraph is also exempted from icing tests.
CS 25.207(c) must be met in the landing configuration within Appendix C icing, adding a specific binding obligation.
CS 25.207(d) receives the same mandatory treatment as 25.207(c) for landing-configuration icing tests.
Take-off distance rule CS 25.105 is expressly exempted from the partial Appendix O icing obligation.
The take-off speeds rule CS 25.107 is also excluded.
CS 25.109 (accelerate-stop distance) does not need to be met in Appendix O icing per this exception.
The take-off path rule CS 25.111 is exempted for the partial Appendix O icing case.
The rule for take-off distance on dry runways, CS 25.113, is likewise excluded.
CS 25.115 (take-off climb) is on the exclusion list for partial Appendix O icing.
The en-route climb/descent requirements of CS 25.121 are excluded from the mandatory icing demonstration.
The limit-climb rule CS 25.123 is also exempted.
Longitudinal control rule CS 25.143(b)(1) is on the list of excluded requirements.
CS 25.143(b)(2) is likewise excluded from the Appendix O exit requirement.
The lateral-directional control rule CS 25.143(c)(1) is exempted.
Manoeuvring speed requirement CS 25.149 is excluded from the partial Appendix O icing set.
The specific stall-warning paragraph is listed as an exclusion.
The flap-position stall rule CS 25.207(c) is exempted.
CS 25.207(d) is also excepted from the obligation.
The direct-lift-control stall rule CS 25.207(e)(1) is excluded.
CS 25.1420 is referenced as an optional comparative-analysis method; it offers a permissible approach rather than imposing a requirement.
Take-off climb requirement CS 25.121(a) is excluded from the Appendix O icing demonstration.
CS 25.123(c) is exempted from the Appendix O icing compliance set.
Longitudinal-control paragraph CS 25.143(b)(1) is excluded.
CS 25.143(b)(2) is also excluded.
CS 25.149 is exempted from the icing demonstration.
The stall-warning rule CS 25.201(c)(2) is on the exemption list.
CS 25.207(c) must still be met in landing configuration for Appendix O icing.
CS 25.207(d) is likewise mandatory for landing-configuration Appendix O icing tests.
Referenced only as an optional analytical method for compliance; it does not impose a new requirement.
The rule fixes the load-distribution limits of CS 25.23 as immutable when operating in icing.
CS 25.25 weight limits are incorporated as hard limits that cannot be relaxed for icing flight.
Centre-of-gravity limits in CS 25.27 are locked in; no relaxation is allowed for icing.
Minimum weight is defined as the lowest weight that still satisfies every applicable rule in CS-25, establishing CS-25 as the benchmark for determining that value.
The paragraph tells designers to calculate unusable fuel in accordance with CS 25.959, thereby importing that rule’s technical method and limits into this requirement.

The phrase links the permission to use removable ballast specifically to the flight requirements located in Subpart B, clarifying that the rule applies only when demonstrating compliance with those particular requirements.
Simply points the reader to the associated AMC for non-binding explanatory material; it adds no extra obligation.
The paragraph requires the aeroplane to comply with all performance rules found in Subpart B, thereby importing those requirements here.
Imports the flight-condition criteria from CS 25.119 that the balked-landing procedures must address.
Likewise brings in the missed-approach conditions defined in CS 25.121(d) for which procedures must be established.
Directs the reader to non-binding AMC that explains acceptable ways to develop the required procedures.
Offers advisory material on how to account for time delays when demonstrating compliance with (h)(3).
Requires that accelerate-stop distance be evaluated per the criteria already specified in CS 25.109.
Imports the landing-distance determination rules from CS 25.125 into this brake-wear requirement.
Points to the corresponding AMC that explains acceptable means of showing compliance with the worn-brake rule.
This note directs the reader to AMC 25.103, which offers non-binding guidance on how to show compliance with the stall-speed rule.
The formula for VCLMAX relies on the manoeuvre defined in paragraph 25.103(c); therefore that paragraph’s conditions are brought into (a).
The parenthetical points to AMC 25.103(b) for acceptable means of compliance with the trim-speed test condition.
Provides a cross-reference to AMC 25.103(b) for additional explanatory guidance on performing the deceleration manoeuvre.
Provides a direct link to AMC 25.103(c), which contains non-binding guidance specific to the deceleration manoeuvre in this paragraph.
Paragraph (d) explicitly states that its minimum-speed margin is "in addition to" the requirements already set in 25.103(a), importing those obligations.
This parenthetical points to AMC 25.103(d) for advisory information on demonstrating compliance with the stick-pusher margin rule.
The applicant must calculate the take-off speeds as set out in CS 25.107, so the technical rules of that CS are imported here.
CS 25.109 provides the accelerate-stop distance definition that must be followed when complying with this paragraph.
The take-off path must be determined using the criteria of CS 25.111; the reference imports those mandatory criteria.
CS 25.113 details how to calculate take-off distance and run, so its methods become obligatory by this cross-reference.
The net take-off flight path must follow CS 25.115; the paragraph imports that rule’s performance standards.
The icing-case assessment only applies if the configuration is the same as that used to meet CS 25.121(b); the clause pulls in that condition.
CS 25.21(g) sets the general icing flight criteria; referencing it brings those overarching icing limits into this paragraph.
The climb-gradient degradation is judged against values calculated per CS 25.121(b); the reference supplies the comparison standard.
The ‘actual-to-net’ reduction in CS 25.115(b) provides the numerical yardstick used to decide if additional icing data are required.
VMCG has to be the value that is established under CS 25.149(e); this imports that calculation method into the VEF rule.
VMC used in the 1.10 × VMC formula must be the VMC that is established in compliance with CS 25.149.
The selected V2 must allow the aircraft to meet the climb-gradient performance required by CS 25.121(b).
The speed increment to be added to VR has to be calculated following the method laid down in CS 25.111(c)(2).
V2 must also give the manoeuvring capability that CS 25.143(h) specifies, so that handling qualities are preserved.
The AMC provides non-binding guidance on how to verify VMU speeds derived from free-air data.
The speed that ensures V2 is reached before 35 ft must be found using the accelerate-climb method of CS 25.111(c)(2).
This AMC offers explanatory material on applying the VLOF/VMU percentages stated in sub-paragraph (iv).
Take-off distances used for the VR-5 kt comparison must be calculated in accordance with CS 25.113(a)(1).
AMC 25.107(e)(3) supplies advisory methods for demonstrating the VR-5 kt take-off-distance check.
‘Scheduled’ take-off distances referenced here have to be the ones established under CS 25.113(a).
AMC No. 1 provides advisory information on assessing the effect of procedural variations on safety and take-off distance.
AMC No. 2 gives further non-binding guidance for handling variation effects referenced in paragraph (e)(4).
VFTO must enable the climb-gradient performance that CS 25.121(c) requires for the en-route climb segment.
VFTO must also allow the manoeuvring capability defined in CS 25.143(h), linking take-off speed to handling qualities.
Directs the reader to the associated AMC, which gives non-binding advice on how to comply with the whole of CS 25.109.
Points to advisory material that explains acceptable methods for the dry-runway calculation in paragraph (a).
Provides a non-binding pointer to the AMC material that also covers dry-runway methodology, which is referenced within the wet-runway rule.
Limits the allowable wheel-brake stopping force to the value already demonstrated when complying with CS 25.101(i).
References AMC material that explains how to determine anti-skid efficiency and apply it to the friction curve.
Points to advisory text describing acceptable methods for the grooved/porous runway friction option.
Provides a pointer to guidance covering recommended reverse-thrust procedures and associated compliance considerations.
Simply tells the reader where to find non-binding explanatory material; it adds no obligation itself.
The take-off path has to follow the detailed procedures laid out in CS 25.101(f), so those external rules become mandatory here.
Points engineers to advisory material that explains paragraph (b); it carries no regulatory force.
States that the determination must follow the procedures already set in sub-paragraph (a), bringing those conditions into paragraph (c).
Likewise requires compliance with the rules in sub-paragraph (b) when establishing the take-off path.
Uses CS 25.105(a)(2) as the trigger: only if that rule calls for an icing analysis does paragraph (c)(5) apply.
Requires the ice accretion selection to follow the criteria laid out in CS 25.21(g).
Requires compliance with CS 25.21(g) when choosing the ‘Final Take-off Ice’ accretion case.
The opening line simply points the reader to the associated Acceptable Means of Compliance for explanatory material; it adds no binding rule.
The distance must be calculated using the take-off path methodology mandated in CS 25.111, so that rule is incorporated here by reference.
Again pulls in CS 25.111 to define the procedure that must be followed when computing the 115 % figure, making that rule applicable.
Provides a non-binding pointer to the AMC sections that explain how to apply the 115 % calculation on different runway conditions.
This item tells the reader to reuse the dry-runway distance already defined in paragraph (a); it does not create a new rule but relies on that earlier calculation.
The wet-runway distance must be derived following the methods set out in CS 25.111, so compliance with that rule is obligatory here.
Offers a cross-reference to explanatory AMC text for the 115 % wet-runway calculation; it is advisory only.
Requires the dry-runway take-off run to be calculated using CS 25.111 methods, therefore importing that rule’s technical criteria.
The 115 % clearway figure must also be generated with a procedure consistent with CS 25.111, so that CS is made binding for this calculation.
Advisory pointer to AMC text that elaborates on applying the 115 % rule when a clearway is used.
For wet-runway clearway cases, the calculation must follow CS 25.111, making that CS directly applicable.
Imports CS 25.111 requirements for determining the 115 % figure on a wet runway with a clearway.
Signals where to find non-mandatory explanatory material covering the 115 % wet-runway clearway calculation.
Engineers must use the take-off distance calculated under CS 25.113(a) when fixing where the flight path starts, so this pulls CS 25.113(a)’s method into 25.115(a).
If the runway is in a different surface condition, the take-off distance must instead follow CS 25.113(b); the reference imports that alternative calculation method.
The net flight-path data have to be based on the actual flight path defined by CS 25.111, so this brings those climb-performance rules into paragraph (b).
Paragraph (b) also relies on the starting point defined in 25.115(a); this internal cross-reference pulls that condition into the climb-gradient calculation.
The paragraph mandates that the applicant must also satisfy every requirement contained in CS 25.119, effectively importing those climb-performance rules into 25.117’s compliance task.
In the same way, the paragraph pulls in all of CS 25.121’s requirements, meaning the applicant must demonstrate compliance with those rules across the stated weight, altitude and temperature ranges.
The AMC gives accepted means of showing compliance, but it is not mandatory; it simply points designers to helpful guidance.
The paragraph requires VREF to be taken from CS 25.125(b)(2)(i), so the calculation method in that rule must be followed.
The phrase 'in accordance with CS 25.21(g)' imports the detailed icing performance requirements of that rule into this climb-gradient condition.
As in the non-icing case, VREF must be established per CS 25.125(b)(2)(i), making that calculation method mandatory here as well.
Points the reader to non-binding AMC material that explains how to interpret and show compliance with the whole of CS 25.121.
Directs applicants to advisory material giving explanatory information for paragraph (a); it has no binding force.
Imports the take-off configuration defined in CS 25.111 as the mandatory set-up in which the climb gradient must be evaluated.
Specifies that the remaining-engine thrust is the value established under CS 25.111 at the moment gear retraction starts.
Provides non-binding explanatory guidance on identifying a more critical power condition along the flight path.
Brings in the weight determined under CS 25.111 as the weight that must be assumed when assessing the climb gradient.
States that the gear-up climb must use the same configuration that was defined in CS 25.111, thereby fixing the test conditions.
Uses the take-off power values obtained under CS 25.111 to define the remaining-engine thrust assumption.
Points to AMC text that helps determine whether a later, more critical power condition exists.
Imports the weight at which the landing gear is fully retracted, as established under CS 25.111, for use in the climb-gradient check.
Requires that icing-condition assessments follow the criteria and ice-accretion levels prescribed in CS 25.21(g).
Cross-refers to the configuration already shown for CS 25.121(b) to ensure the same set-up is used when evaluating icing cases.
Uses the climb-gradient degradation calculated per CS 25.121(b) as a comparison baseline for icing penalties.
Refers to CS 25.115(b) to bring in the allowable actual-to-net gradient reductions against which icing degradation is judged.
Links the final-take-off climb assessment to the end-of-take-off-path configuration established in CS 25.111.
Requires that the weight used in the final-take-off gradient computation is the weight defined at the end of the take-off path under CS 25.111.
Mandates that icing-condition testing for final-take-off performance obey the requirements in CS 25.21(g).
Ensures that the configuration used for the icing comparison is the same as that already demonstrated under CS 25.121(b).
Again uses the climb-gradient degradation calculated under CS 25.121(b) as the reference value for the final-take-off icing check.
Imports the net-take-off flight-path gradient reduction limits from CS 25.115(b) for comparison with icing losses.
Requires that approach-icing performance be evaluated under the icing severity levels specified in CS 25.21(g).
The opening note simply tells the reader to consult AMC 25.123 for non-binding explanatory material that can be used to show compliance.
Sub-paragraph (a) says that the flight paths it is talking about are the ones laid down in 25.123(b); this pulls the content of (b) into the scope of (a).
The phrase also points to 25.123(c), bringing that sub-paragraph’s flight-path definition under the same requirement in (a).
The wording ‘in accordance with CS 25.21(g)’ requires that the ice accretion must be established using the methodology and limits laid down in CS 25.21(g).
The clause compares the climb-gradient loss to the ‘actual-to-net’ reduction already set in 25.123(b), so it brings that definition into the test stated here.
The phrase “in accordance with CS 25.21(g)” pulls in the icing-performance requirements of that rule, so the landing-distance work must respect those conditions.
Requires that the icing-condition speed comparison be done per CS 25.21(g), importing its criteria into this sub-paragraph.
The minimum VREF must not fall below the VMCL value established under CS 25.149(f); the clause brings that speed definition into the current rule.
Links the manoeuvring-capability speed from CS 25.143(h) to the VREF calculation, so that capability requirement bounds the minimum speed here.
This is an internal cross-reference used only to point back to the earlier speed determination; it adds no new rule.
The “in accordance with CS 25.21(g)” wording requires the icing-speed assessment to meet the performance rules in that paragraph.
Uses the manoeuvring-capability speed from CS 25.143(h) as a mandatory floor for VREF under icing conditions.
The phrase requires that the manoeuvring-capability check be done under the conditions set by CS 25.21(g), importing its constraints.
The AMC reference offers non-binding explanatory material; it has no regulatory force but guides how to apply the requirement.
Provides advisory material on runway surface interpretation; it is guidance only and does not add extra rules.
Points to an AMC that explains acceptable brake-use practices; the citation is purely guidance with no mandatory effect.
The paragraph simply points designers to the associated AMC for explanatory material; no extra obligation is imposed.
Again, the text refers readers to the AMC for further advice on how to meet the controllability requirement.
Provides a non-binding pointer to guidance material that explains acceptable means of showing compliance for this engine-failure scenario.
Directs the reader to advisory material that elaborates on workload and illusion assessment during go-around tests.
The test must also satisfy the icing-operation requirements of CS 25.21(g), importing those obligations into this paragraph.
Provides explanatory material on acceptable stick-force characteristics referenced in this paragraph.
Supplies additional non-binding guidance on evaluating stick-force gradients mentioned in the rule.
Directs users to advisory material that illustrates acceptable manoeuvring-capability demonstrations.
Imports the minimum-climb-gradient requirement so that the WAT-limited thrust setting used here meets CS 25.121.
Merely clarifies that the following icing demonstration pertains to compliance with the same core rule; it adds no new duty.
Requires that the icing-condition test also satisfy the operating-limitation criteria set out in CS 25.21(g).
Brings in the CS 25.21(g) icing-operation limits that must be met during the pre-activation flight tests.
States that the force limits in CS 25.143(d) do not apply when evaluating side-stick controllers under this paragraph.
Specifies that the pitch-force criteria of CS 25.145(b) are overridden by the side-stick requirements given here.
Clarifies that the pitch-force limits of CS 25.175(d) are replaced by the side-stick force-suitability assessment in this paragraph.
Points designers to the AMC for non-binding explanatory material on how to show compliance with 25.145(a).
Imports the formally defined trim speed from CS 25.103(b)(6) so that the pitch-down capability must be demonstrated relative to that speed.
Brings in the CS 25.201(d) definition of stall identification to bound the upper end of the speed range for the test.
Again uses the trim speed defined in CS 25.103(b)(6) to specify how the aeroplane is to be initially trimmed for this test case.
Provides non-binding guidance on acceptable test techniques for manoeuvre (b)(1).
Points to AMC material that also covers manoeuvre (b)(2), offering the reader additional explanatory information.
References the AMC that specifically explains the manoeuvre described in paragraph (b)(2).
Refers back to AMC 25.145(b)(1) for related guidance applicable to the manoeuvre sequence.
Points to AMC 25.145(b)(1) as guidance also relevant for manoeuvre (b)(3).
Cites AMC 25.145(b)(2) for supplementary guidance concerning manoeuvre (b)(3).
Signals that additional, non-binding explanatory material for paragraph (e) is available in AMC 25.145(e).
Makes the performance requirements already set in paragraph (c) apply to the additional retraction cases defined in paragraph (e), thereby extending those mandatory obligations.
Requires the go-around to start from the thrust/power setting established by CS 25.161(c)(2), importing that external condition into the test.
Points the reader to the Acceptable Means of Compliance for this entire section; it offers explanatory material but imposes no binding obligation.
Directs users to non-binding AMC material that explains acceptable ways to demonstrate compliance with paragraph (a).
Incorporates all the requirements of paragraph (a) by stating that four-engine aeroplanes must also meet them, thereby importing those obligations.
Provides a link to guidance material that illustrates acceptable means of complying with the roll-response requirement in paragraph (d).
Requires four-engine aeroplanes to use the configuration defined in paragraph (b) when showing compliance, effectively importing those conditions.
Points to AMC guidance for acceptable methods to show compliance with the all-engines-operating lateral-control criteria; it carries no direct obligation.
The rule header sends applicants to AMC 25.149, which contains non-binding explanatory material on how to show compliance with the whole CS 25.149 section.

Feathering is only allowed if the automatic system is good enough to meet the climb-performance rules in CS 25.121, so this cross-reference brings those climb requirements into the acceptability check.
Points designers to AMC 25.149(e) for recommended methods of establishing VMCG in compliance with paragraph (e).
Directs applicants to AMC 25.149(f) for acceptable means of demonstrating VMCL tests required by paragraph (f).
Refers readers to AMC 25.149(g) for guidance on determining VMCL-2 with multiple-engine failures.
Offers a link to AMC 25.149(h)(3) that explains how to assess the required lateral-control roll capability.
Provides non-binding advice in AMC 25.149(h)(4) on evaluating propeller-position effects during failure demonstrations.
This clause imports the climb speed, configuration and power established by CS 25.123(a); those values set the conditions under which four-engine trim must be shown.
This AMC is cited only to point readers to non-binding explanatory material; it carries no mandatory obligations.
The requirement applies only under the flight conditions defined in CS 25.175, so those conditions are imported into this paragraph.
The climb condition in CS 25.175(a) defines one of the specific configurations for which the speed-return test must be met.
The approach condition from CS 25.175(c) is imported to set another flight configuration for compliance with the return-to-speed rule.
The landing condition described in CS 25.175(d) is also brought in as a scenario where the 10 % speed-return criterion applies.
The cruising condition of CS 25.175(b) is referenced to establish the tighter 7.5 % return-to-trim-speed requirement.
The AMC is mentioned only to give advisory information on interpreting the stick-force gradient requirement.
Directs the applicant to use the ‘most adverse’ centre-of-gravity position determined under CS 25.27 when performing this stability test.
Brings in the definition of ‘maximum cruising power’ from CS 25.1521 so the power setting used in the test matches the certified operating limitation.
Uses the speed range already specified in 25.175(b)(1) to define the upper limit for the low-speed cruise evaluation.
Calls back to the flap, CG, and weight conditions established in 25.175(b)(1) so they apply unchanged to the low-speed cruise case.
Specifies that the gear-extended stability test must use the same flap, CG, and weight configuration defined earlier in 25.175(b)(1).
The header simply points the reader to the associated AMC for non-binding explanatory material; it does not add any new obligation.
By citing paragraph (a), it brings the same configurations and speed range into the applicability of the proportional-force rule in (c).
This cross-reference directs designers to advisory guidance that explains how to demonstrate compliance with paragraph (c).
It uses the sideslip angle limit defined in (c) as the starting condition for the additional rudder-force requirements in (d).
The reference informs the reader where to find advisory material on acceptable means of showing compliance with paragraph (d).
The parenthetical note points the reader to AMC 25.181, importing non-binding explanatory material that shows one way to comply with the rule.
This AMC is cited only to give explanatory information about VSR1; it does not impose any additional obligation.
The sub-item again points to the same AMC for explanatory material on VSR1, purely as non-binding guidance.
The text makes paragraph (b) apply in every flight condition already listed in paragraph (a), importing those conditions here.
Paragraph (b) requires the aircraft to be capable of meeting all stall-performance limits set by CS 25.203 under the stated conditions.
The AMC gives advisory detail on flap, gear and deceleration-device positions; it is referenced only for guidance.
This cross-reference brings in the speed definition from CS 25.103(b)(6) to specify how the aircraft must be trimmed.
The paragraph states that the listed test procedures are mandatory for showing compliance with the stall criteria of CS 25.203.
AMC 25.103(c) is cited solely to give non-binding advice on conducting the deceleration during the test.
The AMC provides recommended practice for turn-stall deceleration rates and is referenced only as guidance.
This AMC is mentioned to supply acceptable methods of identifying a stall; it carries no binding force.
AMC 25.201(d)(3) is cited for additional explanatory material on this specific stall cue, with no regulatory obligation.
The paragraph simply points the reader to AMC 25.203, which offers non-binding guidance on how to comply with the stall-handling requirements that follow.
The device has to give a warning in all aircraft configurations already listed in paragraph (a); this pulls those configurations into the paragraph (b) requirement.
This imports the warning-onset speed defined in paragraph (c) so that paragraph (b) applies at that speed.
This also brings in the additional speed requirement from paragraph (d) for the same purpose.
The words “Except for…” exclude the specific icing-case warning of paragraph (h)(3)(ii) from the ‘same means’ rule stated here.
Points the reader to non-binding AMC material that explains acceptable ways to comply with this paragraph.
The stall identification speed must be the one determined under CS 25.201(d); that external rule defines the reference speed used here.
Provides AMC guidance on how to show compliance with the speed-margin requirements of paragraphs (c) and (d).
States that the requirements here are in addition to those already imposed by paragraph (c); therefore it imports paragraph (c) obligations.
Uses the centre-of-gravity location defined in CS 25.103(b)(5) to set up the test condition for this paragraph.
Directs readers to AMC text that explains acceptable methods for demonstrating compliance with paragraphs (c) and (d).
The definition of ‘stall’ used in paragraph (e) is the one established by CS 25.201(d), so that external criterion governs the margin assessment here.
Links the take-off ice accretion definition back to CS 25.21(g), importing those ice shapes for the required demonstration.
Imports the en-route ice accretion definitions from CS 25.21(g) for the test condition described in bullet (2).
References CS 25.21(g) again, this time to define the holding-phase ice shapes that must be considered.
Brings in the approach-phase ice accretions from CS 25.21(g) for the configuration in bullet (4).
Uses CS 25.21(g) to define the landing and go-around ice accretions required for the final test condition.
Specifies that the ‘most critical’ ice shapes for this icing-before-activation case are those established under CS 25.21(g).
Paragraph (i) is only applicable when showing compliance with paragraph (h); this reference limits its applicability accordingly.
Requires that the buffet-onset margin criteria of CS 25.203 also be met while demonstrating alternate stall-warning means in icing.
States that the stall demonstration must follow CS 25.201 procedures, except as modified in the next clause.
Explicitly waives the deceleration-rate requirement of CS 25.201(c)(2) for this particular icing demonstration.
The paragraph lets the applicant show freedom from ground-looping while using the 90° cross-wind component that CS 25.237 already specifies, so it pulls that wind-velocity condition into this test.
“In accordance with CS 25.21(g)” pulls in that paragraph’s specific criteria for determining the applicable icing conditions during the landing evaluation.
The heading simply points readers to the related AMC, offering non-binding guidance on how to meet the rule.
The paragraph requires that the demonstrated maximum speeds be used when setting operating limits in accordance with CS 25.1505, thereby importing that regulation’s criteria.
By saying 'Except as provided in sub-paragraph (d)', it excludes the conditions covered by 25.251(d) from the prohibition stated in (c).
This parenthetical points to an AMC that offers acceptable means of compliance for the buffet-onset envelope requirement; it carries no binding obligation itself.
This points designers to the associated AMC for non-binding explanatory material; it does not itself impose any extra rule, only offers guidance.
The citation simply directs the reader to advisory material for further explanation of acceptable means of compliance with the nose-down pitching moment criterion.
The paragraph requires that the controllability criteria of CS 25.143(g) be satisfied at VFC/MFC, importing those performance obligations.
Rudder control requirements from CS 25.147(f) must also be met at VFC/MFC, so its standards apply here.
Longitudinal stability criteria of CS 25.175(b)(1) are pulled in and must hold at the stated maximum speed.
Directional stability standards of 25.181 must also be satisfied at the defined speed, extending those obligations here.
The phrase 'Except as noted in CS 25.253(c)' carves out an explicit exception to the minimum-speed rule, pointing the reader to paragraph (c) for alternate limits.
The ice accretion assessment must follow the methodology of CS 25.21(g), importing those procedural rules.
Controllability standards from CS 25.143(g) must be met at the icing-condition maximum speed, so they are incorporated here.
Rudder control requirements of CS 25.147(f) are likewise mandated at the specified icing speed.
Longitudinal stability criteria of CS 25.175(b)(1) must be met under the icing-condition speed definition.
Directional stability criteria of CS 25.181 are also required at the maximum speed in icing conditions.
This line merely directs the reader to the associated AMC for advisory material; it brings in non-binding guidance without creating any new obligation.
The requirement in (b) only applies when the aeroplane is in the out-of-trim state defined in (a), so this reference narrows the scope of the test condition.
‘Except as provided in (d)…’ means the demonstration called for in (c) is waived if the circumstances of (d) apply, importing an exception to the rule.
This clause likewise exempts cases covered by (e) from the demonstration otherwise required by (c).
The paragraph states that compliance with the provisions of (a) must be demonstrated over the stated g-range, pulling the obligation from (a) into the flight-test context.
The ‘If the procedure in (c)(2) is used…’ phrase conditions the extra testing on adoption of the simplified method described in (c)(2).
The paragraph directs that additional flight tests extend up to the g-limits specified in (c)(1); this imports the numerical limits as a binding requirement.
The sentence clarifies that the following load-factor constraints apply only to the flight tests carried out under paragraph (a).
Imports the limit manoeuvring load factors defined in CS 25.333(b) to cap the loads that need not be exceeded during the test.
Similarly brings in the limit manoeuvring load factors of CS 25.337 to define the maximum loads acceptable during the demonstration.
References CS 25.251(e) to identify the buffet-onset envelope used for determining additional manoeuvring load factors that need not be exceeded.
Specifies that the overspeed-recovery capability must be shown while the aeroplane is in the out-of-trim state defined earlier in (a).
The trim-run used for the mistrim calculation must respect the stabiliser travel stops mandated by CS 25.655(b), so those limits are imported as binding constraints.

References the mandatory circuit-protective device of CS 25.1357(a) as the potential means to show the 25.1309(b) compliance that could negate the added requirement.
Shows that this requirement is located in Subpart F (Equipment), helping users understand the larger regulatory context.
This pulls in the detailed technical rules of CS 25.1387 that the complete position-light system must comply with.
The paragraph also makes the system subject to all requirements contained in CS 25.1397.
Paragraph (a) tells the designer that its lighting obligation does not apply when the conditions in paragraph (e) are met, so it imports that exception.
The allowance for obstructed visibility only applies if the rear position light is installed in the manner required by CS 25.1385(c), so this brings that mounting condition into paragraph (e).
Paragraph (e) relies on the definition of dihedral angle A that is provided in paragraph (d), importing that geometric definition for clarity.
Paragraph (a) tells designers that the position-light distribution must satisfy all the detailed criteria laid out later in paragraph (b), so it imports those requirements into (a).
The rule makes compliance with the minimum horizontal-plane intensity values defined in CS 25.1391 mandatory.
Vertical-plane intensities must meet the numeric values listed in CS 25.1393, so that external CS becomes binding here.
The definition of variable I is tied back to the minimum intensities in CS 25.1391, making those figures part of the calculation engineers must use.
Maximum overlap intensities cannot exceed the limits given in CS 25.1395 unless specific higher-output conditions are met, so that CS sets the hard ceiling.
Where higher overlap intensities are considered, the comparison is made against the main-beam minima in CS 25.1391, bringing those values into the assessment.
The paragraph also cross-checks against the minima in CS 25.1393 when judging acceptable higher intensities, therefore importing that CS’s figures.
Identifies that the paragraph sits within the Equipment subpart, indicating topical scope without adding any new obligations.
This cross-reference carves out an exception; if the conditions of CS 25.1389(b)(3) are met, the intensity limits in 25.1395 do not apply.
The light’s colour must conform to the colour standards defined in CS 25.1397, so that external rule becomes part of the certification basis here.
The subpart heading shows that this requirement sits within the Equipment subpart, clarifying the general domain (aircraft equipment) to which it applies.
Identifies that the rule is talking about the descent device that CS 25.810(a) already requires, importing its definition into this paragraph.
Limits the obligation to the liferafts that are required under CS 25.1415, thereby framing the scope of this stowage rule.
Pulls in the technical standard for the static line prescribed by CS 25.1415, making compliance with that standard mandatory.
Clarifies that the stowage requirement concerns the signalling device mandated by CS 25.1415.
Brings the life-preservers required by CS 25.1415 into the scope of this paragraph’s stowage rules.
Makes the lifeline stowage requirement conditional on the applicant seeking ditching certification under CS 25.801.
The requirement targets ditching equipment for aeroplanes that are to be certificated under CS 25.801, so this citation defines the set of aeroplanes the rule applies to.
The flotation-means requirement activates only for aeroplanes not certificated for ditching under CS 25.801, so the reference sets a conditional exclusion.
Points the applicant to the associated Acceptable Means of Compliance; purely advisory guidance with no direct obligation.
States that additional power-plant ice-protection rules from Subpart E may apply, expanding the applicant’s compliance scope beyond the airframe.
Makes the detection/activation requirements of paragraph (e) apply to all flight phases unless shown otherwise, thereby importing those obligations into every phase.
Requires the operator to place the ice-protection operating procedures into the AFM, extending the rule’s effect to that document.
The heading points readers to AMC 25.1420 for non-binding explanatory material that can be used to show compliance.
Shows that the entire §25.1420 rule sits within Subpart F (Equipment), establishing its regulatory context.
The rule says the aircraft must meet CS 25.1419 in addition to §25.1420, importing those icing requirements.
Requires compliance with CS 25.1419(e) for the relevant icing conditions.
Imports the obligations of CS 25.1419(f) into §25.1420(c).
Imports the obligations of CS 25.1419(g) into §25.1420(c).
Imports the obligations of CS 25.1419(h) into §25.1420(c).
Allows comparative analysis to be used instead of the test/analysis methods prescribed in §25.1420(b).
States that the alternative analysis must still demonstrate the safe-operation objective set in §25.1420(a).
Permits the same comparative analysis to substitute for the methods referenced in §25.1420(c).
The paragraph pulls in the specific ultimate inertia load values from CS 25.561(b)(3); the restraint must be designed to withstand those loads, so this reference sets the design condition.
The paragraph tells designers to use the failure-safety criteria of CS 25.1309(a) when evaluating radio and electronic equipment, so it brings those external rules into the compliance task.
Just like 25.1309(a), this reference imports the probability and severity criteria of CS 25.1309(b) that must be considered when showing compliance.
The rule mandates that the power-supply design for radio and electronic equipment must meet all the detailed requirements stated in CS 25.1355(c); therefore it imports those obligations directly.
By stating "required by this CS-25," the paragraph limits its interference rule to equipment that CS-25 itself mandates, pulling that list of required systems into scope.
The main rule just directs the reader to the AMC, bringing in non-binding explanatory material for designers.
The system-level pressure control must ensure that the proof-pressure rule of (a)(1) is satisfied, so this earlier requirement is imported here.
The clause pulls in the deformation-under-limit-load requirement of (a)(2) to apply it at system level.
It also makes the ultimate-load pressure criterion from (a)(3) a system design obligation.
The fatigue-effects requirement of (a)(4) is explicitly incorporated into the system-pressure control rule.
The environmental-condition performance rule of (a)(5) is likewise made part of the system design obligation.
If flammable hydraulic fluid is used, the system must also comply with the flammability/material safety requirements of CS 25.863.
The rule pulls in CS 25.1183 so that fire-protection standards for engine compartments apply when flammable hydraulic fluid is used.
It also requires compliance with CS 25.1185 concerning flammable fluid fire-protection in designated areas.
CS 25.1189 on shut-off means is incorporated so that hydraulic systems using flammable fluid meet those fire-safety provisions.
The marking/placarding rule of CS 25.1541 is referenced to ensure the chosen hydraulic fluid is correctly identified on the aircraft.
The root paragraph simply tells the reader to consult AMC 25.1436 for non-binding explanatory material; it adds no obligation itself.
The text requires the applicant to meet the system-safety requirements of CS 25.1309, importing those obligations into the pneumatic-system context.
Any pneumatic component that is an engine accessory must satisfy CS 25.1163, so those power-plant rules are pulled into this paragraph.
The clause creates an exception to the 125 % pressure limit by referring to sub-paragraph (b)(6); hence that sub-paragraph’s conditions override the normal limit.
A parenthetical ‘See AMC 25.1436(b)(3)’ points to advisory material that explains acceptable means of compliance but imposes no additional rule.
Within bullet (ii) the same cross-reference again states that the 125 % limit does not apply when the conditions of (b)(6) are met.
The paragraph allows transient pressures to exceed the limit defined in (b)(3)(ii); it therefore pulls that limit in as the baseline condition being relaxed.
The ‘See AMC 25.1436(c)(2)’ note directs readers to advisory test-method guidance without creating any binding obligation.
The opening parenthetical points readers to AMC 25.1438 for non-binding explanatory material; it does not itself impose any requirement but helps designers find supporting guidance.
The text says the pneumatic system must comply with CS 25.1309, pulling all of that rule’s safety-analysis obligations into this paragraph.
Paragraph (b) states that its listed requirements apply to the equipment required by 25.1439(a), so it pulls that earlier obligation into its own scope.
The text explicitly requires the equipment to meet the design criteria of CS 25.1441, importing those regulatory requirements into this paragraph.
The paragraph makes compliance with the specific design rules in CS 25.1443 mandatory for any supplemental-oxygen installation, so those external requirements are imported verbatim.
The paragraph also forces compliance with CS 25.1453, pulling its detailed requirements into the certification basis for the oxygen equipment.
This AMC reference provides non-binding guidance on how to show the oxygen system is hazard-free; it does not impose additional obligations.
The reference points to an AMC that explains acceptable methods for approving flow rates and equipment above 40 000 ft; it offers guidance only.
The header indicates that the rule sits in Subpart F but, within this sentence, it does not itself add obligations or set applicability.
Directs the reader to non-binding Acceptable Means of Compliance that explain how to satisfy the rule; it does not impose extra obligations itself.
Points to advisory material that elaborates acceptable means of meeting the altitude-driven equipment requirements in this paragraph.
Provides a source of explanatory guidance for the design and distribution of the dispensing units referenced in this sub-paragraph.
Offers non-binding design guidance for demand and quick-donning oxygen equipment required for flight-deck crew.
Refers to AMC text that illustrates acceptable methods for showing compliance with the outlet and unit-number requirement.
Links to advisory material giving acceptable practices for portable oxygen equipment provided to cabin crew.
This sentence tells the designer to fully meet the crashworthiness and security rules already written in CS 25.795(d); it imports those requirements here without restating them.
The opening line simply points engineers to the associated AMC for non-binding explanatory material; it does not impose any technical duty.
The requirement to record PA-system crew audio only applies if the fourth channel is available as defined in sub-paragraph (c)(4)(ii).
Paragraph (b) ties its microphone-installation rule specifically to the recording obligation set in sub-paragraph (a)(2).
The four-channel recording requirement applies only to the audio types first listed in sub-paragraph (a).
This clause is an alternative that activates only when the crew-station microphones specified in (c)(4)(i) are absent or already captured elsewhere.
Later in the paragraph, it ensures all sounds from the microphone source listed in (c)(1) are continuously recorded.
It likewise mandates uninterrupted recording from the source identified in (c)(2).
The same uninterrupted-recording rule is extended to the additional crew-member microphone source described in (c)(4).
A safety assessment for unintended deployment must be carried out to the hazard-analysis standards of CS 25.1309, importing its full methodology.
Points the reader to the AMC for non-binding guidance on how to comply with this rule.
Shows that this requirement sits in Subpart F – Equipment, helping users understand the subject area it governs.
Imports the airspeed-accuracy standards that the data sources feeding the recorder must meet.
Brings in altitude-accuracy criteria that the recorder’s data sources have to satisfy.
Calls up directional-data accuracy standards that the supplying sources must comply with.
Requires deployable recorders to meet the same technical specifications already laid down for cockpit voice recorders.
Mandates that the recorder container conform to the crash-survivability specs set for voice-recorder containers.
The section header directs readers to AMC 25.1460, which contains non-binding explanatory material to aid compliance with the rule.
If the recorder is deployable, it must comply with the crash-survivability standard already laid down in CS 25.1457(d)(7), importing those technical requirements.
This clause mandates that the data link recorder container meet the same performance specifications as the cockpit voice recorder container described in CS 25.1457(g).
Paragraph (a) requires the equipment to comply with all the obligations set out in sub-paragraph (b), therefore importing those requirements into the applicability of (a).
Paragraph (a) also points to sub-paragraph (c); this makes the test-containment requirements of (c) mandatory for any equipment governed by (a).
By citing sub-paragraph (d), paragraph (a) obliges the equipment to meet the location and safety positioning criteria defined in (d).
This points readers to the associated Acceptable Means of Compliance, offering non-binding guidance rather than creating any obligation.
This CS marks the starting point of the list of operating limitations that must be established, defining the scope of what the rule covers.
This CS marks the end point of the referenced series, completing the scope of operating limitations that must be established.
This CS begins the set of rules that dictate how the information must be presented to the crew, establishing conditions for compliance.
This CS ends the referenced range, indicating the full set of conditions governing the form and presentation of the required information.
The paragraph tells designers that the minimum speed margin must at least meet the value calculated under CS 25.335(b), thereby importing that rule’s quantitative criteria into this requirement.

It also mandates that any higher margin found necessary during flight tests carried out per CS 25.253 becomes the binding minimum, so the flight-test rule’s findings are incorporated here as an additional requirement.

This reference tells the reader that the design manoeuvring speed VA used here is the one calculated under CS 25.335(c); it pulls that calculation method into this rule so engineers must consult that CS when establishing VA.
VFE may not exceed the design flap speed VF that must be calculated in accordance with CS 25.335(e); this pulls that calculation requirement into the speed limit condition.
The VF value referenced must also be the one established per CS 25.345, so this clause imports those design-speed rules as part of the limitation.
Specifies that the VMC to be published is the value derived in accordance with CS 25.149, effectively importing that calculation standard into this limitation requirement.
The paragraph requires the safe extension/retraction speed to be worked out using the criteria in CS 25.729, so that section’s tests are pulled into this requirement.
The allowed flight speed with gear extended is limited by the safe-speed derived from CS 25.729, importing that section’s methodology into this paragraph.
This is a pointer to the Acceptable Means of Compliance that explains one accepted way to meet 25.1519; it provides advice only and imposes no binding requirement.
The rule says the limits that were calculated using CS 25.23 must become operating limits, so it imports the results of CS 25.23 into this requirement.
Similarly, it imports the limits derived under CS 25.27 and makes them mandatory operating limitations.
The section header simply points readers to the related AMC, which is advisory material and not legally binding.
This cross-reference supplies the formal definition of icing conditions that should be used when setting the time-interval limits.
The ambient temperature limit for the aircraft must be the same value established under CS 25.1043(b), directly importing that requirement.
The paragraph twice points to AMC 25.1523 to offer non-binding explanatory material on how to decide minimum crew; it does not itself impose extra obligations.
CS 25.1525 defines the kinds of authorised operations, which must be taken into account when deciding minimum crew; this imports those operational categories into the evaluation.

The paragraph borrows the positive limit load factors defined in CS 25.333(b) to cap the load-factor limits that have to be set; engineers must look to that referenced rule to know the maximum allowed values.
The sentence simply points the reader to the AMC, which is non-binding explanatory material.
The weight must be proven by showing compliance with the applicable provisions of the whole CS-25 code, so those external rules are pulled into this requirement.
Maximum landing weight must meet all other applicable CS-25 rules, so those provisions become conditions for compliance.
The landing climb requirements of CS 25.119 are imported as a specific test that defines the allowable landing weight.
The approach climb requirement in CS 25.121(d) is another mandatory performance test for setting maximum landing weight.
Minimum take-off distance must be derived by showing compliance with the wider CS-25 code, bringing those rules into this paragraph.
CS 25.109 sets detailed ground run distance criteria that must be satisfied when establishing minimum take-off distance.
CS 25.113 provides accelerate-stop/accelerate-go distance rules that form part of the required proof for minimum take-off distance.
The parenthetical points to the AMC for optional explanatory material on wet-runway distances; it adds no binding rule.
The extremes for variables must correspond to points where the aircraft meets the rest of CS-25, so those provisions are imported as the benchmark.
Paragraph (c) only applies to aeroplanes that were certified under CS 25.1420(a)(1); this reference sets that applicability boundary.
Aeroplanes certified under CS 25.1420(a)(2) are also within the scope, establishing when the limitation is required.
The sub-paragraph mandates that the aeroplane must comply with all relevant CS-25 requirements for the intended ETOPS diversion time, importing those certification standards.

ref.ref_target: Subpart G – Operating Limitations and Information
ref.comment: The heading is included only to show the rule’s placement within CS-25; it does not create obligations.
The heading directs readers to AMC 25.1541, which is advisory material explaining acceptable means of compliance, not a binding rule.
Paragraph (b) explicitly states it only applies to the markings and placards listed in 25.1541(a), pulling that earlier list into its applicability.
This note directs readers to AMC 25.1543 for explanatory guidance on compliance; it provides advice only and does not itself impose any requirement or change applicability.
This points the reader to the associated AMC, offering non-binding guidance on how to comply with the rule but imposing no obligation itself.
The paragraph specifies that only the airspeed limitations called for by CS 25.1583(a) are subject to the readability requirement, thereby importing that regulation’s scope into this rule.
Refers readers to the AMC for non-binding explanatory material on how to comply with the marking requirements; it adds no extra obligation.
The paragraph tells designers that aerodynamic control markings have to satisfy all the mandatory details already laid down in CS 25.677.
Along with CS 25.677, this cross-reference imports the specific marking rules in CS 25.699 that must also be met for aerodynamic controls.
This citation identifies which visual indicators (those required by CS 25.729(e) for retractable gear) fall under the marking obligation in this paragraph.
The heading simply points readers to the related AMC, which offers non-binding explanatory material and suggested compliance methods.
This parenthetical sends the reader to the AMC for paragraph (a), providing advisory guidance without adding any regulatory obligation.
Paragraph (c) requires emergency-exit placards to comply with CS 25.811, thereby importing the detailed technical requirements of that rule.
The parenthetical note merely directs readers to the related AMC, providing non-binding explanatory material without changing the rule itself.
The bullet says the Flight Manual must include information required by CS 25.1583, so it imports those mandatory content rules into this paragraph.
This closes the referenced range, bringing in all content obligations up through CS 25.1587 that the manual must also cover.
The sentence requires that the sections of the manual identified in CS 25.1583 be supplied, approved, and separated from unapproved text, so it pulls those requirements into (b).
Along with CS 25.1583, this reference extends the same furnish-and-approve obligation to the sections defined up through CS 25.1587.
The lead-in sentence merely points readers to AMC 25.1583 for explanatory guidance; it adds no binding rule.
The paragraph requires applicants to use the manoeuvring speed that has already been established under CS 25.1507, thereby importing that earlier test result into this limitation list.
It points to CS 25.1515(a) to define exactly what ‘landing-gear operating speed’ means, ensuring the same terminology is used here.
This item obliges the AFM to include every power-plant limitation that CS 25.1521 already mandates, directly importing those limits.
It pulls in the instrument-marking rules of CS 25.1549 so that the AFM contains the data needed to mark those instruments correctly.
Same sentence also imports the marking requirements that appear at the other end of the range, CS 25.1553.
The paragraph requires that the weight-and-CG limits that were established under CS 25.1519 are reproduced in the AFM.
A second reference ensures that any weight-distribution limits derived from CS 25.1519 are also carried over verbatim.
CS 25.29 is cited so that the meaning of ‘empty weight’ used in the loading data matches the regulatory definition.
It brings in the crew-number determination made under CS 25.1523, making that result part of the published operating data.
Applicants must list the kinds of operation that CS 25.1525 already approved, so the AFM exactly mirrors those authorisations.
The extremes of temperature and altitude must match the envelope defined under CS 25.1527, importing those performance limits.
Any additional operating limitations that CS 25.1533 generated must be reproduced here, directly extending those rules to the AFM.
The parenthetical note simply tells users where to find advisory material for paragraph (i); it imposes no obligation.
This citation points to non-binding AMC guidance that explains how to treat runway-contaminant limits; it is not itself a rule.
The paragraph tells engineers to list operating conditions where the fuel‐system independence requirement of CS 25.953 applies, so it imports that rule to define when the POH information is needed.
It requires the buffet onset envelopes that were established in accordance with CS 25.251 to be included, thereby pulling that performance requirement into the information section.
The requirement for temperature-conversion data only applies when the temperature indicator fitted to meet CS 25.1303(a)(1) is not a free-air type.
Take-off performance requirements of CS 25.115 must be used when generating the AFM data specified here.
Enforces that the en-route climb/descent criteria of CS 25.123 are applied to the performance information entered in the AFM.
Landing performance data in the AFM must be derived using the rules set out in CS 25.125.
Specifies that VSR values placed in the AFM have to be determined exactly as required by CS 25.103.
The AFM must include procedures established under CS 25.101(f), bringing those take-off procedure requirements into the manual.
Likewise, procedures mandated by CS 25.101(g) for landing are required to be reproduced in the AFM.
This cross-reference defines which limitations and information the listed procedures must relate to, linking the AFM material back to CS 25.1533.
Points readers to non-binding AMC material that explains how to present abnormal-configuration landing data; it has advisory value only.
Directs readers to the AMC that gives non-binding guidance on acceptable means of compliance with this rule.
Shows the section’s location within Subpart G, signalling that the requirements relate to operating limitations and information.
The opening line directs the reader to AMC 25.1592 for explanatory material; it brings in non-binding guidance without adding a technical duty.
This is merely a page-header reminder that the rule sits in Subpart G; it has no effect on obligations or scope within the paragraph.
The parenthetical tells the reader to consult AMC 25.1592 for details on runway condition; it provides advisory information only.
Points to the Acceptable Means of Compliance for this rule; offers non-binding guidance on acceptable ways to show the required susceptibility assessment.
Shows that this requirement sits within Subpart G (Operating Limitations and Information), helping readers understand the broader regulatory context.
The lead-in sentence simply tells the reader to consult AMC 25.1701 for non-binding explanatory material, so it imports guidance but sets no obligations.
The phrase “Except as provided for in subparagraph (c)” pulls in the exclusions listed in (c), narrowing the scope of the EWIS definition given in (a).
It cites the definition in (a) to explain that the same definition also applies to EWIS components located inside certain enclosures, thereby extending that definition’s coverage.
The words “Except for the equipment indicated in subparagraph (b)” bring in the equipment already covered in (b) and exempt it from the new exclusions being introduced in (c).
By stating that certain items “are excluded from the definition in subparagraph (a),” paragraph (c) actively removes those items from the scope of the definition created in (a).
Simply directs the reader to the associated AMC, which offers non-mandatory guidance on how to comply with CS 25.1703.
25.1705 uses this rule to identify one category of systems (pilot-compartment view) whose EWIS must be treated as part of the system when showing compliance.
The lavatory-fire-protection rule is cited so that any EWIS associated with that system falls under 25.1705 obligations.
Cargo-compartment fire-detection systems covered by CS 25.858 are brought into the scope of 25.1705 for EWIS treatment.
Fuel-tank ignition-prevention systems identified in CS 25.981 must have their EWIS assessed under 25.1705.
Engine-ignition systems subject to CS 25.1165 are included so their wiring is treated as an integral part of the system.
Fire-detector systems that must meet CS 25.1203 are brought within 25.1705’s EWIS compliance scope.
Flight and navigation instruments covered by CS 25.1303(b) must have their associated wiring assessed per 25.1705.
Power-source capacity and distribution systems defined in CS 25.1310 are included within the EWIS requirements.
Systems that must meet the lightning-protection rule CS 25.1316 have their EWIS captured by 25.1705.
Instruments using a power supply per CS 25.1331(a)(2) are listed so that their wiring must meet 25.1705 considerations.
CS 25.1351 (General electrical requirements) is cited to ensure EWIS for such systems is handled under 25.1705.
Electrical distribution systems that comply with CS 25.1355 must also treat their wiring as integral per 25.1705.
Systems where CS 25.1360 applies (precautions against injury) bring their EWIS into 25.1705 scope.
Electrical supplies for emergency conditions under CS 25.1362 are explicitly included for EWIS compliance.
Electrical appliances, motors, and transformers covered by CS 25.1365 must handle their wiring per 25.1705.
Electronic equipment addressed by CS 25.1431(c) is brought into the EWIS-treatment requirements of 25.1705.
Electronic equipment addressed by CS 25.1431(d) is likewise included so its wiring must meet 25.1705 obligations.
This opening line merely points engineers to AMC 25.1707 for non-binding explanatory material; it brings in no additional obligation.
The citation to CS 25.1709 defines which systems must be redundant; those systems are the ones that must meet the separation rule in paragraph (k).
This citation merely points designers to explanatory Acceptable Means of Compliance material; it adds no binding requirement and therefore functions as neutral guidance.
The root paragraph merely points readers to the AMC for explanatory material; it does not impose any obligation.
This reference limits the identification requirement to systems whose redundancy is mandated by CS 25.1709, importing that redundancy condition into this paragraph.
Simply points the reader to the associated AMC for explanatory guidance; it carries no binding requirement.
This clause obliges EWIS components to comply with the fire- and smoke-protection standards already defined in CS 25.831(c).
Imports the fire-protection requirements of CS 25.863, making them directly applicable to EWIS components.
The paragraph simply points the reader to AMC 25.1715 for non-binding explanatory material; it does not add any obligation.
This sub-paragraph orders that EWIS bonding components must meet all of CS 25.899, thereby importing those certification requirements.
The reference defines the type of aeroplane (“earthed electrical systems”) for which the bonding return-path requirement applies, linking the condition to CS 25.1353(e).
The parenthetical note points designers to the AMC for advisory information; it does not impose any obligation but offers guidance on how to comply.

The requirement to be compatible with the circuit-protection devices ‘required by CS 25.1357’ imports those devices’ specifications into this paragraph, making them a condition that EWIS design must satisfy.
This directs readers to the associated AMC, which offers explanatory guidance on acceptable ways to comply with the rule but adds no mandatory requirements.
The paragraph tells readers to consult AMC 25.1721, which contains non-binding explanatory material that supports compliance with this rule.
The citation points the reader to the associated AMC for explanatory material; it carries no binding obligation but offers guidance on how to comply with this paragraph.
The paragraph mandates that EWIS components comply with all of CS 25.863, effectively importing those fire-safety requirements into the EWIS context.

The phrase “in accordance with the requirements of CS 25.903(b)” makes compliance with that engine installation rule mandatory for EWIS design, so the obligations of CS 25.903(b) are imported into this paragraph.
This cross-reference directs designers to meet the specific rotor-burst/fire provisions in CS 25.903(d)(1); its requirements are therefore brought into this paragraph.

The paragraph requires the EWIS fire-protection design to comply with the specific fire-zone criteria laid down in CS 25.1189, thereby importing those requirements and making them mandatory for this context.
The sentence directs the applicant to comply with CS 25.1529 when preparing EWIS Instructions for Continued Airworthiness, importing all the detailed requirements of that CS section.
This opening note simply directs the reader to the related AMC, which is advisory only and imposes no binding requirement.
The parenthetical citation merely points to advisory material that explains this construction/installation requirement.
The citation directs readers to advisory guidance for electrical bonding, without creating additional obligations.
The paragraph mandates that the APU installation must meet the system-safety requirements found in CS 25.1309.
It explicitly states that compliance with the specific failure-condition criteria of CS 25.1309(b) is not required for the listed hazardous effects, carving out an exception.
This parenthetical simply refers the reader to advisory material offering further explanation of the exception; it imposes no obligation.
Cross-refers to the envelope-establishment requirement in (e)(1)(ii) so the reader knows which envelope must include cold-soak effects; it does not add new obligations.

The paragraph relies on CS 25.333 to define the negative-acceleration flight envelopes; therefore the conditions from CS 25.333 are imported and must be used when demonstrating compliance with this requirement.
This points the reader to AMC 25J955 for non-binding explanatory material; it adds no extra obligation but offers a recognised means of showing compliance.
The amount of unusable fuel must be the one already determined under CS 25.959, so that rule’s criteria are imported here to set the limit for this paragraph.
The parenthetical note directs designers to AMC 25J955(a)(2)(iii) for acceptable methods; it offers guidance only and imposes no extra requirements.
The paragraph relies on the operating-limitation altitude already established under CS 25J1527; this imports that altitude as a condition for the vapour-lock demonstration.
Sub-paragraph (b) states that the test it describes is the same as that laid down in 25J961(a), thus pulling the obligations and test parameters from paragraph (a) into (b).
The parenthetical note tells the reader to consult AMC 25J991 for non-binding explanatory material, pulling advisory guidance into consideration for this rule.
The words “fuel system requirements of this subpart” tie the definition of a main pump to the fuel-system rules found elsewhere in Subpart J, thereby importing that scope into the paragraph.
By saying “other than those in sub-paragraph (b),” the text excludes the pumps discussed in 25J991(b) from being treated as main pumps, carving out an explicit exception.
The paragraph borrows the wheels-up landing conditions defined in CS 25.721(b); the fuel-system protection must be demonstrated for those same conditions.
States that the fuel-valve support rule applies in addition to the shut-off valve rules of CS 25J1189, so designers must also comply with that CS.
The paragraph orders that every oil line must satisfy all the technical criteria laid down in CS 25J993, so this text brings those external standards into force for this design task.
For oil lines and fittings located in a fire zone, the designer must additionally comply with CS 25J1183; the paragraph pulls those fire-protection rules into this requirement set.
The heading shows this rule sits inside Subpart J, so its requirements only apply to auxiliary power unit installations covered by that Subpart.
The paragraph orders that every oil shut-off must comply with all the technical criteria found in CS 25J1189, pulling those requirements into this rule.
This points the reader to the AMC, which provides non-binding guidance on how to meet the cooling requirement.
The paragraph tells the applicant they must satisfy all the requirements of CS 25J1041 by carrying out tests, so it pulls those obligations in.

The paragraph explicitly states that compliance with CS 25J1041 must be demonstrated, bringing all the obligations of that earlier cooling-system rule into this paragraph for the critical conditions under evaluation.
The parenthetical 'See AMC 25J1093' merely points the reader to advisory guidance; it adds no binding obligation or scope.
The text conditions use of non-essential APU intakes on compliance with CS 25J1093(b), importing that rule’s technical standards.
Referring to Table 1 of CS 25.1093(b)(2) pulls in specific ground-icing test conditions that must be used unless more critical ones are chosen.
The closing ‘See AMC 25J1093(b)’ directs applicants to non-mandatory advisory material explaining acceptable means of compliance.
It imports the marking requirements from CS 25.1555(a), meaning the APU control labels must follow the established marking standard.
The paragraph defers to CS 25J1189 for the detailed criteria on shutting off flammable fluids during a fire, so those fire-protection rules become mandatory here.
